description: From Middle French mamillaire, or its source, Late Latin mamillaris.

adjectives.description: mammillary (comparative more mammillary, superlative most mammillary)

entries.meaning: Resembling a breast or nipple in shape or form.

examples: On the other hand, no woman who had ever borne a child (even in her own childhood) could be accepted, no matter how free she was of mammilary blemishes.

entries.meaning: (geology, speleology) A carbonate coating formed through the precipitation of calcium carbonate onto existing rock below the water surface in cave pools.
(anatomy) A mammillary body, one of a pair of small round bodies, located on the undersurface of the brain, that form part of the limbic system.
